p: Two mathematical models applicable to a pandemic like COVID-19 are stochastic and SIR (susceptible-infected-recovered). Stochastic modeling entails all mathematical models with the random variable in the function assignment. That is, stochastic modeling uses random assignment for forecasting functions, which is helpful in the early stages of virus propagation [ 28]. The SIR model has a reasonable predictive power applied to situations where individuals infect each other directly [ 29]. However, in recent years spatial structures, and in particular network theory (as a model for road networks or flight connections) and metapopulation, have proved relevant in understanding the complexity of virus propagation [ 30, 31].
